channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Vatican Bank Looks to Shed Its Image as an Offshore Haven
item.description: The bank, long shrouded in mystery, has been under pressure to bring its practices in line with European norms to curb money-laundering and terrorist-financing.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Our first pillar is transparency,” said Ernst von Freyberg, appointed Vatican Bank’s president by Pope Benedict XVI in February.

item.title: U.S. Combat Commanders Should Handle War Zone Investigations, Panel Says
item.description: After flaws in the case of Marines accused in a 2005 Iraq massacre prompted a review, a Defense Department panel proposed that American troops should not be investigated by the branches in which they serve.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER

item.title: Southern Africa Development Fund Mired in Debt
item.description: A program financed by the Agency for International Development is dissolving because of mismanagement, insider dealings and a lack of federal oversight.
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.dc:creator: By BARRY MEIER and RON NIXON
item.media:description: The Southern Africa Development Fund, long led by the civil rights leader Andrew Young, above, was founded to aid businesses in several sectors.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Wave of Violence Continues
item.description: A series of bombings in Baghdad and the northern city of Mosul killed at least 30 people and wounded dozens on Thursday, Iraqi officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.N. Court Acquits 2 Serbs of War Crimes
item.description: In a surprise verdict, two close aides of the former Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic were found not liable for crimes committed by combat units they commanded.
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: Bangladeshi Lab Struggles to Identify Rana Plaza’s Dead
item.description: Anger over the Rana Plaza collapse has intensified the pressure on a small lab struggling to make DNA matches with the remains of about 300 unidentified victims.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Taslima Akhter for The New York Times
item.media:description: The relatives of a victim of the Rana Plaza collapse grieve among bodies from the disaster at a morgue in Dhaka. At least 301 victims have not been identified.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Weapons Cache Found
item.description: Soldiers in northern Nigeria uncovered a hidden arms cache that the authorities said might belong to Hezbollah, the military and secret police said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Tunisia: Activist Fined but Faces More Charges Over Protests
item.description: A court convicted a Tunisian member of a Ukrainian feminist group Thursday of carrying an “incendiary object” and fined her $182, but prosecutors were considering more charges.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Inching Toward a Truce
item.description: Myanmar’s government and ethnic Kachin rebels on Thursday reached a tentative deal to de-escalate fighting and continue a political dialogue.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: El Salvador: Doctors Can Induce Birth to Save Woman, Official Says
item.description: A 22-year-old woman who was denied an abortion by El Salvador’s Supreme Court can terminate her pregnancy at the first sign of danger, the health minister said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY

item.title: Mexico City Journal: Satirical Look at Rich Delights Mexican Moviegoers
item.description: “We Are the Nobles,” the director Gaz Alazraki’s satirical look at the habits of wealthy Mexicans, has become the highest-grossing Mexican film ever.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gaz Alazraki, the director of “We Are the Nobles,” a satirical look at Mexico’s upper class.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Drone War Is Far From Over
item.description: Attacks by remote control are alive and well in some corners of Pakistan, where they have caused lasting damage on tribal communities.
item.dc:creator: By AKBAR AHMED

item.title: The Lede: Kremlin-Owned Network Hires Larry King
item.description: The news that the Russian government’s satellite news network Russia Today, or RT, has hired Larry King prompted a wave of derisive comments on Twitter.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and ANDREW ROTH

item.title: BBC Faces New Allegations of Sexual Abuse
item.description: The BBC said 152 accusations of sexual abuse and harassment by 81 current and former employees had been lodged since the case involving Jimmy Savile emerged.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:credit: Express Newspapers, via Associated Press Images.

item.title: Commissioner Seeks End to Roaming Fees in Europe
item.description: The European Union’s commissioner for digital policies is pressing for one set of rules governing the market for cellphones in Europe.
item.dc:creator: By KEVIN J. O’BRIEN
item.media:description: Neelie Kroes, the European commissioner for digital policies, is proposing to shake up the union’s telecommunciations system.

item.title: Plague of Corruption Rises Anew in Indonesia
item.description: Despite their democratic turn, Indonesian political parties are increasingly turning to graft to finance their operations.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: IHT Special: In Dubai, Cost and Waits for School Pose Hurdles
item.description: Amid growing demand, parents move to reserve slots years in advance and to pay primary school fees that sometimes rival American college tuition.
item.dc:creator: By SARA HAMDAN

item.title: Assad Warns Israel, Claiming Stockpile of Russian Arms
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria spoke confidently in an interview with Hezbollah-owned television as his opposition appeared to be fracturing further.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Forces of the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, in Qusayr on Thursday. Syrian rebels under siege near the Lebanese border pleaded for help.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: May 30
item.description: A sand sculpture to spread awareness about the adverse effects of tobacco consumption on the eve of World No Tobacco Day.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A sand sculpture created by artist Sudarshan Pattnaik in Puri, Orissa, as part of an awareness campaign on the eve of World No Tobacco Day. The World Health Organization first designated May 31 as a day to spread awareness about the adverse effects of tobacco consumption in 1987.

item.title: European Union and Britain Wrangle Over Social Security Rules
item.description: The European Commission vowed to take the British authorities to court, accusing them of breaking bloc rules over who can receive benefits. But Prime Minister David Cameron has promised to loosen British ties to the bloc.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain wants to loosen European Union ties.

item.title: U.S. Pressure Rises to End Bangladesh Trade Status
item.description: After several deadly factory disasters in Bangladesh, Obama administration officials remain conflicted over what measures would work best to improve labor conditions there.
item.dc:creator: By IAN URBINA
item.media:description: Rescue workers searched for trapped garment workers following the collapse of the Rana Plaza building in Savar, Bangladesh, last month.

item.title: Resisting Conformity in Thailand
item.description: Thai schools are a drill sergeant’s dream. Discipline and conformity rule, but some students have begun calling for the abolition of the “mechanistic” education system.

item.title: Hints of a Schism in Pakistani Taliban After Deputy’s Death
item.description: One subgroup unilaterally announced a successor after the militants acknowledged Wali ur-Rehman’s death in a drone attack. A Taliban spokesman also said the group would take revenge for Mr. Rehman’s death.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN and IHSANULLAH TIPU MEHSUD

item.title: U.N. Court Acquits 2 Serbs of Balkan War Atrocities
item.description: A United Nations court on Thursday acquitted two former allies of former Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic of setting up and arming notorious Serb paramilitary gangs that committed atrocities in Bosnia and Croatia during the Balkan wars in the 1990s.
item.category: International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Homage Paid to ‘Rite of Spring,’ With Stravinsky and Without
item.description: Theaters in London and Paris marked the centennial of a revolutionary, game-changing moment in modern music and dance.
item.dc:creator: By ROSLYN SULCAS
item.media:description: A scene from the Akram Khan Company's "iTMOi" (In the Mind of Igor), inspired by "The Rite of Spring."
